meaning: To be without knowledge in some particular matter; to understand something vaguely; to act blindly
equivalents: To be in the dark about something

meaning: An urgent problem that is difficult to solve.
equivalents: A sore point

literal: To take someone by the heart/soul.
meaning: To excite, to move or touch deeply; to cause anxiety.
equivalents: To pull at someone’s heartstrings; to touch someone’s heart

literal: To throw itself into someone’s eyes.
meaning: To arrest attention, to be striking, to be conspicuous.
equivalents: To catch someone’s eye; to stare someone in the face

literal: To be a head taller than someone.
meaning: To be far superior to someone (mentally or morally).
equivalents: To be head and shoulders above someone

meaning: To display mutual hostility.
equivalents: To be at daggers drawn; to be at swords’ points with someone.

literal: To turn like a squirrel in a wheel.
meaning: To constantly busy oneself, to toil, to bustle about.
equivalents: To be constantly on the go; to run/go around in small circles; to run around like a squirrel in a cage; to be as busy as a bee; to be busy as a bee/beaver

literal: To take oneself in one’s hands.
meaning: To rouse oneself to renewed activity; to make a determined effort, to regain one’s normal mental state, to regain one’s self-control.
equivalents: To take hold of oneself; to take oneself in hand; to pull oneself together

literal: To be hanging in the air.
meaning: To be undecided (said of a question or matter); to be in an uncertain position (said of a person).
equivalents: To be in the air

literal: To be hovering in the clouds
meaning: To live in a dream world, to indulge in day-dreams not attending to everyday matters; to let one’s thoughts wander
equivalents: To be up in the clouds; to go/to be wool-gathering

literal: To put one’s soul into something
meaning: To put all one’s efforts into an undertaking; to do something whole-heartedly.
equivalents: To put one’s heart and soul into something

literal: To fly into a little kopeck.
meaning: To involve a great expense; to cost a large sum of money.
equivalents: To cost a pretty penny

meaning: To become famous; to be remembered as a remarkable event.
equivalents: To make history; to go down in history

literal: Not fit to be soles of someone’s shoes.
meaning: Someone or something is quite inferior to; not to be compared with, not nearly as good as.
equivalents: Not fit to hold a candle to someone; to be not a patch on someone.

literal: To get up with one’s left foot foremost.
meaning: To be in a bad or an irritable state of mind.
equivalents: To get out of bed on the wrong side

meaning: To rise very early in the morning, at daybreak.
equivalents: To rise with the lark/sun

meaning: Entirely valueless, worth nothing at all.
equivalents: Not worth a rap/a farthing/a hill of beans.

literal: To tell fortunes by coffee ground
meaning: To make groundless statements; to make wild guesses.
equivalents: To tell someone’s fortune from the tea-leaves in his cup

meaning: To show approval, to gratify; to show indulgence towards, to pander to someone.
equivalents: To pat someone on the back

literal: To stroke someone against his hair.
meaning: To do or say something contrary to someone’s prejudices, opinions, or habits.
equivalents: To rub/stroke someone the wrong way

meaning: Terribly hungry.
equivalents: Hungry as a hunter

literal: Ready to fall through the ground.
meaning: One earnestly wishes to disappear; one feels so ashamed or embarrassed that he wishes that the earth would swallow him up.
equivalents: He wishes the ground would open under him

meaning: Something that cannot be done or explained quickly; something that takes a long time to be accomplished; a drawn out affair.
equivalents: A long story.

literal: One’s soul has gone into one’s heels.
meaning: Someone is greatly alarmed by what is happening or anticipated to happen; terribly frightened.
equivalents: One’s heart sank into one’s boots; to have one’s heart in one’s mouth.

meaning: Someone who has a very poor memory; someone who is forgetful, absent-minded.
equivalents: To have a head like a sieve.

literal: To live like a cat and a dog.
meaning: To be constantly snapping, bickering and quarrelling.
equivalents: To fight like cats and dogs.

literal: To live as on a volcano.
meaning: To be in constant anticipation of trouble.
equivalents: To sit on a powder-keg; to be living on the edge of a volcano; to be sitting on a volcano

literal: To cook kasha (a dish of cooked grain or groats)
meaning: To start a complicated, risky or troublesome affair.
equivalents: To stir up trouble; to make a mess of something.

literal: To come into a blind alley.
meaning: To find oneself in a desperate position.
equivalents: To reach a deadlock

meaning: A hopeless situation; a state of affairs from which it’s difficult to find a way out.
equivalents: A vicious circle

meaning: An open thoroughfare; also used to indicate that there is nothing standing in one’s way.
equivalents: The green light

literal: To know something lengthwise and crosswise.
meaning: To know something thoroughly in all its details.
equivalents: To know something inside out.

literal: To know all the entrances and exits
meaning: To know all the details or intricacies; to be thoroughly familiar with what is to be done under the circumstances.
equivalents: To know one’s way around; to know all the ins and outs; to know the ropes.

literal: To know something as well as one’s own five fingers.
meaning: To know something thoroughly; to be quite familiar with something.
equivalents: To know something like the palm of one’s hand.

meaning: A master of one’s craft.
equivalents: A clever pair of hands; skillful/deft fingers.

meaning: To gain influence; to attain promotion; to make a prosperous career.
equivalents: To go up/rise in the world; to climb up the ladder.

head_ru: ИДТИ В ОГОНЬ И В ВОДУ
transliteration: itti v ogon’ i v vodu
literal: To go into fire and water.
meaning: To submit to any ordeal, to encounter or face the greatest dangers or hardest chances, to be ready to do anything for someone or something.
equivalents: To go through fire and water

meaning: To be dependent on someone.
equivalents: To be led by; to be under someone’s thumb.

meaning: To follow someone’s example; to be someone’s disciple.
equivalents: To follow in someone’s footsteps

meaning: Outstanding, exceptional, out of the ordinary.
equivalents: Out of the common run

literal: To have a head on one’s shoulders.
meaning: To be intelligent and reasonable; to be able to think for oneself.
equivalents: To have a good head on one’s shoulders.

meaning: Racked with anxiety, in a state of acute discomfort, uneasiness or suspense.
equivalents: To be on tenter-hooks; to be on pins and needles; to be on thorns/wires.

meaning: Without producing any effect; without paying the slightest attention
equivalents: Like water off a duck’s back.

meaning: The place is so crowded that one can’t push one’s way through.
equivalents: Packed like sardines

literal: As if someone or something has fallen through the ground.
meaning: Someone or something has suddenly and unexpectedly disappeared in a mysterious manner, without a trace.
equivalents: To vanish into thin air; as though the earth had opened and swallowed it up.

meaning: Someone feels depressed or unhappy.
equivalents: A heavy heart; to have something weigh upon one’s heart.

meaning: A part so small as to be insignificant
equivalents: A drop in the ocean/bucket

literal: To drive out one wedge with another.
meaning: To destroy the results of an action by the means this action has been previously caused.
equivalents: To fight fire with fire; like cures like; nail drives out nail.

meaning: A deliberate action intended for effect.
equivalents: A fine gesture; beau geste

meaning: A problem that is very hard to solve; a person hard to deal with.
equivalents: A hard nut to crack

meaning: One has no firm convictions; one adapts himself to the prevailing opinions, views, tastes; one avoids taking action or making a decision until he sees which move will be most favourable to himself.
equivalents: To see/find out which way the wind blows; to see which way the cat jumps; as changeable as a weathercock.

literal: To buy a cat in a sack
meaning: To buy a thing without knowing its real value or quality.
equivalents: To buy a pig in a poke

literal: For the hens to laugh at.
meaning: It’s funny, ridiculous, absurd, silly.
equivalents: It’s enough to make a cat laugh

literal: To pour water on someone’s mill-wheel.
meaning: Indirectly to help someone (usually an opponent) by one’s actions.
equivalents: To play into someone’s hands; to bring grist to someone’s mill.

literal: To catch fish in turbid water.
meaning: To try to benefit from other people’s troubles; to try to gain advantage for oneself from a disturbed state of affairs; to try to make a calamity by means of personal gain.
equivalents: To fish in troubled waters

meaning: To rage, to fulminate, to speak with threats and anger.
equivalents: To rant and rave; to hurl thunderbolts; to blow one’s top.

meaning: Someone or something is extremely valuable or useful.
equivalents: To be worth one’s/its weight in gold

meaning: To give sudden and intense attention to what is being said or to what is going to be said.
equivalents: To prick up one’s ears.

meaning: Something about a person is quite obvious by the look on his face.
equivalents: It’s written all over his face.

literal: To strike a blow from round the corner.
meaning: To act in an underhand, treacherous, sly manner.
equivalents: A stab in the back

literal: To catch up with someone; to follow
meaning: someone very closely; to be close behind.
equivalents: To be at someone’s heels

literal: Not to see farther than one’s nose.
meaning: To lack imagination or insight; to be conscious only of circumstances round one; the situation one is now in or events that are presently happening.
equivalents: Not to see an inch beyond one’s nose; to see no further than one’s nose

literal: It doesn’t come out of the one’s head
meaning: Something remains permanently in one’s mind; one is unable to get something out of one’s mind.
equivalents: It sticks in one’s mind.

meaning: A person whose mind is filled with visionary thoughts; one who is too imaginative instead of attending to things in a practical way; a day-dreamer.
equivalents: To be in another world; to have one’s head in the clouds.

meaning: Despondent; petrified with fear or astonishment.
equivalents: More dead than alive.

literal: Neither a picket nor a yard.
meaning: To be very poor; not to have a roof over one’s head.
equivalents: To have neither house nor home. Beside the point, out of place; for no apparent reason; quite irrelevantly.

meaning: A mediocre person.
equivalents: Neither fish, flesh nor fowl.

literal: Not to peep out one’s nose.
meaning: One can’t go outside.
equivalents: One can’t even stick his nose out of the house

literal: To lead someone round a finger.
meaning: Without any difficulty to make a person do exactly what one wishes; to be able to handle or manage someone with ease; to cajole, persuade some artfully
equivalents: To twist/turn someone round one’s little finger.

meaning: You’ll lick your fingers clean
equivalents: Finger-licking good

literal: To write like a chicken with its claw
meaning: To write quite indecipherably
equivalents: One’s handwriting is like chicken tracks

literal: to turn up under one’s hand
meaning: Something turns up without one’s having to make a special search for it.
equivalents: To come to hand

literal: To bring a pill to someone.
meaning: To say or do something unpleasant, annoying, insulting.
equivalents: To give someone a bitter pill to swallow

meaning: To show hostility, anger, or resentment; to display a threatening attitude
equivalents: To show one’s teeth

meaning: To run away; to escape.
equivalents: To take to one’s heels; to show a clean pair of heels; to take flight.

meaning: To get into a difficulty or into trouble; to find oneself in an awkward or dangerous situation.
equivalents: To get into a scrape/mess/tight corner; to be in a spot; to be/be caught in a bind

meaning: The latest fashion; the latest craze.
equivalents: The last word in fashion.

meaning: The final circumstance of a series that makes a situation unbearable.
equivalents: The last straw.

meaning: To be satisfied with what one has already achieved or accomplished without striving for more.
equivalents: To rest on one’s laurels

meaning: To cause someone to regain consciousness; to revive someone.
equivalents: To bring someone round/to

literal: To press someone against the wall.
meaning: To put someone in a difficult or embarrassing position, forcing him to do or admit something; to put someone in desperate straits.
equivalents: To drive/push someone to the wall; to drive someone into a corner; to pin someone down

meaning: To disregard an insult; to endure an offence patiently, without resistance or complaint.
equivalents: To swallow a bitter pill.

meaning: To fall silent; to stop talking.
equivalents: To lose one’s tongue.

literal: To chop straight from the shoulder.
meaning: To speak in a direct, outspoken, blunt way; without reserve or evasion; to act without previous intention or preparation, promptly, impulsively; to do something without giving it a thought.
equivalents: Straight from the shoulder

literal: To dig a pit for someone
meaning: To cause someone trouble; to plunge into intrigue against someone; to do someone harm.
equivalents: To make /prepare a pitfall for someone.

meaning: To dwell on one’s favourite topic; to be on one’s pet subject.
equivalents: To mount/ride one’s hobby/hobby-horse

meaning: A lucid mind, a clear intellect, a bright spirit.
equivalents: A clear head

meaning: To feel great shame.
equivalents: To burn with shame

literal: To sit down on a shoal.
meaning: To get into an extremely difficult situation; to be in unsatisfactory circumstances, especially with little money.
equivalents: To be on the rocks; to be in low water; to be in a tight corner.

meaning: To depart in haste
equivalents: To take/sling one’s hook; to take to one’s heels; to clear out

meaning: To laugh secretly to oneself while being outwardly serious.
equivalents: To laugh in/up one’s sleeve

meaning: To look deep into the matter; to investigate the matter thoroughly; to try to grasp the crux of a matter; to tackle something at its source
equivalents: To get to the heart/root of something.

literal: To look at someone or something with different eyes.
meaning: To look at or assess someone or something in a different way.
equivalents: To look with another eye upon.

literal: To look down at someone from above.
meaning: To regard someone as inferior or with disapproval; to treat someone haughtily, disdainfully.
equivalents: To look down on someone; to look down

meaning: To appropriate part of the results of someone else’s labour.
equivalents: To skim the cream off.

meaning: To spend a large sum of money recklessly; to squander money.
equivalents: To throw one’s money about

literal: Full right up to the throat.
meaning: One has had too much of something; one is surfeited with something.
equivalents: To be fed up with something; to have one’s fill of something.

literal: To lose the ground under one’s feet.
meaning: To lose self-confidence in one’s occupation, social position or convictions.
equivalents: To feel the ground slipping away from under one’s feet.

literal: To go into one’s own self.
meaning: To become withdrawn, uncommunicative; to become less sociable and more reserved.
equivalents: To retire into oneself

meaning: Peremptorily to ask a person, whose presence is unwelcome, to leave the house, room, etc.
equivalents: To show someone the door

literal: To fall from the sky to the earth.
meaning: To be disillusioned; to abandon fantasy and return to practical realities.
equivalents: To come down to earth.

meaning: To be completely under someone’s authority; to be very obedient, almost to the point of servility.
equivalents: To be at someone’s beck and call; to dance attendance upon someone; to toe the line

meaning: To engage in idle talk; to talk continuously; to chatter.
equivalents: To wag one’s tongue
